title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Myblog
text:
import sqlite3
import pandas as pd
def query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month):
    conn=sqlite3.connect(db_file) 
    c = conn.cursor()

    # Construct the SQL query using f-strings
    sql_query = f"""
        SELECT S.NAME AS Name, S.LATITUDE AS Latitude, S.LONGITUDE AS Longitude, C.Name AS Name, 
               T.Year, T.Month,T.Temp
        FROM temperatures T
        LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
        LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
        WHERE C.Name = '{country}'
          AND T.Year BETWEEN {year_begin} AND {year_end}
          AND T.Month = {month}
        GROUP BY S.NAME, T.Year, T.Month
    """

    # Execute the SQL query and fetch the results into a DataFrame
    df = pd.read_sql_query(sql_query, conn)

    # Close the database connection
    conn.close()

    return df


query_climate_database(db_file = "your_database_file.db",
                       country = "India", 
                       year_begin = 1980, 
                       year_end = 2020,
                       month = 1)

DatabaseError: Execution failed on sql '
        SELECT S.NAME AS Name, S.LATITUDE AS Latitude, S.LONGITUDE AS Longitude, C.Name AS Name, 
               T.Year, T.Month,T.Temp
        FROM temperatures T
        LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
        LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
        WHERE C.Name = 'India'
          AND T.Year BETWEEN 1980 AND 2020
          AND T.Month = 1
        GROUP BY S.NAME, T.Year, T.Month
    ': no such table: temperatures

title: Myblog
text:
import sqlite3
import pandas as pd
def query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month):
    conn=sqlite3.connect(db_file) 
    c = conn.cursor()

    # Construct the SQL query using f-strings
    sql_query = f"""
        SELECT S.NAME AS Name, S.LATITUDE AS Latitude, S.LONGITUDE AS Longitude, C.Name AS Name, 
               T.Year, T.Month,T.Temp
        FROM temperatures T
        LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
        LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
        WHERE C.Name = '{country}'
          AND T.Year BETWEEN {year_begin} AND {year_end}
          AND T.Month = {month}
        GROUP BY S.NAME, T.Year, T.Month
    """

    # Execute the SQL query and fetch the results into a DataFrame
    df = pd.read_sql_query(sql_query, conn)

    # Close the database connection
    conn.close()

    return df


query_climate_database(db_file = "your_database_file.db",
                       country = "India", 
                       year_begin = 1980, 
                       year_end = 2020,
                       month = 1)

DatabaseError: Execution failed on sql '
        SELECT S.NAME AS Name, S.LATITUDE AS Latitude, S.LONGITUDE AS Longitude, C.Name AS Name, 
               T.Year, T.Month,T.Temp
        FROM temperatures T
        LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
        LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
        WHERE C.Name = 'India'
          AND T.Year BETWEEN 1980 AND 2020
          AND T.Month = 1
        GROUP BY S.NAME, T.Year, T.Month
    ': no such table: temperatures

title: HW 1, Database
text:
# import all packages I might need 
import pandas as pd 
import sqlite3

import numpy as np
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from plotly.io import write_html
import plotly.express as px





# create a database called db_file 
conn= sqlite3.connect("db_file")




df = pd.read_csv("temps.csv")
df_iter = pd.read_csv("temps.csv", chunksize = 100000)


#clean and prepare the data 
def prepare_df(df):
    df = df.set_index(keys=["ID", "Year"])
    df = df.stack()
    df = df.reset_index()
    df = df.rename(columns = {"level_2"  : "Month" , 0 : "Temp"})
    df["Month"] = df["Month"].str[5:].astype(int)
    df["Temp"]  = df["Temp"] / 100
    return(df)


df = prepare_df(df)


#creat a table with the temperature data
for i, df in enumerate(df_iter):
    df = prepare_df(df)
    df.to_sql("temperatures", conn, if_exists = "replace" if i == 0 else "append", index = False)


#creats a table with all the stations 
url = "station-metadata.csv"
stations = pd.read_csv(url)
stations.to_sql("stations", conn, if_exists = "replace", index=False)

27585



#creats a table with all the countries 
countries_url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mysociety/gaze/master/data/fips-10-4-to-iso-country-codes.csv"
countries= pd.read_csv(countries_url)
countries.to_sql("countries", conn, if_exists = "replace", index=False)

279







#to make sure we have created the database with the three tables we wanted we print a list with our tables
cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute("SELECT name FROM sqlite_master WHERE type='table'")
print(cursor.fetchall())

[('temperatures',), ('stations',), ('countries',)]



cursor.execute("SELECT sql FROM sqlite_master WHERE type='table';")

for result in cursor.fetchall():
    print(result[0])

CREATE TABLE "temperatures" (
"ID" TEXT,
  "Year" INTEGER,
  "Month" INTEGER,
  "Temp" REAL
)
CREATE TABLE "stations" (
"ID" TEXT,
  "LATITUDE" REAL,
  "LONGITUDE" REAL,
  "STNELEV" REAL,
  "NAME" TEXT
)
CREATE TABLE "countries" (
"FIPS 10-4" TEXT,
  "ISO 3166" TEXT,
  "Name" TEXT
)






cmd = \
"""
SELECT T.id, T.month, T.temp
FROM temperatures T
LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(T.id, 1, 2) = SUBSTR(C."FIPS 10-4", 1, 2)
LEFT JOIN stations S ON SUBSTR(T.id, 1, 2) = SUBSTR(S.id, 1, 2)
WHERE C.Name IS NOT NULL

"""
cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute(cmd)
result = [cursor.fetchone() for i in range(10)]  # get just the first 10 results
result

[('AFM00040911', 1, 2.99),
 ('AFM00040911', 1, 2.99),
 ('AFM00040911', 1, 2.99),
 ('AFM00040911', 1, 2.99),
 ('AFM00040911', 1, 2.99),
 ('AFM00040911', 1, 2.99),
 ('AFM00040911', 2, 8.09),
 ('AFM00040911', 2, 8.09),
 ('AFM00040911', 2, 8.09),
 ('AFM00040911', 2, 8.09)]



conn.close()










def query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month):
    
   # this connects it to the database we created earlier 
    conn= sqlite3.connect(db_file)
    
    query = f"""
    SELECT S.NAME AS Name, S.LATITUDE AS Latitude, S.LONGITUDE AS Longitude, C.Name AS Country,
           T.Year, T.Month, AVG(T.Temp) AS Temp
    FROM temperatures T
    LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
    LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
    WHERE C.Name = '{country}'
          AND T.Year BETWEEN {year_begin} AND {year_end}
          AND T.Month = {month}
    GROUP BY S.NAME, T.Year, T.Month
   """
    
    df = pd.read_sql_query(query, conn)
    # this closes the database connction 
    conn.close()
   
    return df


query_climate_database(db_file = "db_file",
                       country = "India", 
                       year_begin = 1980, 
                       year_end = 2020,
                       month = 1)

# I first created a function to calculate the yearly temp coefficient so I will not have to do this calculation within my next function and the work would be presented more clearly 

def calc_temp_coefficient(data_group):
    x = data_group[['Year']].values
    y = data_group['Temp'].values
    if len(x) < 2:
        return np.nan  # this is in case there is not enough data to caluclate the regression 
    lr = LinearRegression()
    lr.fit(x, y)
    return round(lr.coef_[0], 5) 

# a function that shows how the average yearly change in temperature vary within a given country

def temperature_coefficient_plot(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month, min_obs=10 ,**kwargs): 
    conn=sqlite3.connect("db_file")
    
    # SQL query to get the temperature data for a the specified country in a year range and month
    query = f"""
    SELECT S.NAME AS Station_Name, S.LATITUDE AS Latitude, S.LONGITUDE AS Longitude,
           C.Name AS Country, T.Year, T.Month, AVG(T.Temp) AS Temp
    FROM temperatures T
    LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
    LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
    WHERE C.Name = '{country}'
          AND T.Year BETWEEN {year_begin} AND {year_end}
          AND T.Month = {month}
    GROUP BY S.NAME, T.Year, T.Month
    """
  
    # I used .read_sql_querey to read the dtatbase datat and store it as Pandas DataFrame
    df = pd.read_sql_query(query, conn)
    
    # filter stations with at least min_obs years of data value and group them by the station ID 
    df = df.groupby('Station_Name').filter(lambda x: x['Year'].count() >= min_obs)
    
   
     # Calculate the estimated yearly temperature increase for each station
    yearly_changes = df.groupby('Station_Name').apply(
        lambda group: calc_temp_coefficient(group)
    ).reset_index(name='Estimated Yearly Increase (°C)')
    
    
     # Create a Plotly Express scatter mapbox plot
    fig = px.scatter_mapbox(
        df,
        lat='Latitude',
        lon='Longitude',
        hover_name='Station_Name',
        color='Temp',  # Use the calculated column as color
        height=600,
        **kwargs
    )
    
    # Set layout options and styling for the plot
    fig.update_layout(margin={"r":0,"t":0,"l":0,"b":0})
    
    # Return the figure
    return fig







from climate_database import query_climate_database
from climate_database import calc_temp_coefficient
from climate_database import temperature_coefficient_plot

from climate_database import analyze_seasonal_temperature_change


import inspect
print(inspect.getsource(analyze_seasonal_temperature_change))

def analyze_seasonal_temperature_change(db_file, season, country=None, year_range=None):
    # Connect to the database
    conn = sqlite3.connect(db_file)
    
    # Define the SQL query to retrieve temperature data for the specified season
    query = f"""
    SELECT T.Year,
           CASE
               WHEN T.Month BETWEEN 3 AND 5 THEN 'Spring'
               WHEN T.Month BETWEEN 6 AND 8 THEN 'Summer'
               WHEN T.Month BETWEEN 9 AND 11 THEN 'Fall'
               ELSE 'Winter'
           END AS Season,
           AVG(T.Temp) AS Avg_Temperature
    FROM temperatures T
    LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
    LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
    """
    
    # Add conditions for year range and country filter if provided
    if year_range:
        query += f" WHERE T.Year BETWEEN {year_range[0]} AND {year_range[1]}"
        if country:
            query += f" AND C.Name = '{country}'"
    elif country:
        query += f" WHERE C.Name = '{country}'"
    
    # Group the data by year and season
    query += " GROUP BY T.Year, Season"
    
    # Execute the query and read the results into a DataFrame
    df = pd.read_sql_query(query, conn)
    
    # Close the database connection
    conn.close()
   
    # Visualize the data
    fig = px.bar(df, x='Season', y='Avg_Temperature', color='Season', title=f'Average Temperature in {season}')
    fig.show()
    
    return fig




db_file = "db_file"

# Define the year range
year_range = (2000, 2020)

# Define the country (optional)
country = "USA"

# Call the function
analyze_seasonal_temperature_change(db_file, year_range)

    fig = px.line(df, x='Month', y='Avg_Temperature', title='Average Monthly Temperature by Country')
    return fig

def get_data_from_database(db_file):
    conn = sqlite3.connect(db_file)
    query = "SELECT * FROM temperatures"  # Adjust your SQL query accordingly
    df = pd.read_sql_query(query, conn)
    conn.close()
    return df


my_df = get_data_from_database("db_file")
fig = visualize_avg_monthly_temperature_by_country(my_df)

ValueError: Value of 'y' is not the name of a column in 'data_frame'. Expected one of ['ID', 'Year', 'Month', 'Temp'] but received: Avg_Temperature



def visualize_monthly_temperature_trends_for_station(df):
    fig = px.line(df, x='Month', y='Temp', color='Year', title='Monthly Temperature Trends for a Specific Station')
    return fig

def query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month):
    
   # this connects it to the database we created earlier 
    conn= sqlite3.connect(db_file)
    
    query = f"""
    SELECT S.NAME AS Name, S.LATITUDE AS Latitude, S.LONGITUDE AS Longitude, C.Name AS Country,
           T.Year, T.Month, AVG(T.Temp) AS Temp
    FROM temperatures T
    LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
    LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
    WHERE C.Name = '{country}'
          AND T.Year BETWEEN {year_begin} AND {year_end}
          AND T.Month = {month}
    GROUP BY S.NAME, T.Year, T.Month
   """
    
    df = pd.read_sql_query(query, conn)
    # this closes the database connction 
    conn.close()
   
    return df

# I first created a function to calculate the yearly temp coefficient so I will not have to do this calculation within my next function and the work would be presented more clearly 

def calc_temp_coefficient(data_group):
    x = data_group[['Year']].values
    y = data_group['Temp'].values
    if len(x) < 2:
        return np.nan  # this is in case there is not enough data to caluclate the regression 
    lr = LinearRegression()
    lr.fit(x, y)
    return round(lr.coef_[0], 5) 

# a function that shows how the average yearly change in temperature vary within a given country

def temperature_coefficient_plot(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month, min_obs=10 ,**kwargs): 
    conn=sqlite3.connect("db_file")
    
    # SQL query to get the temperature data for a the specified country in a year range and month
    query = f"""
    SELECT S.NAME AS Station_Name, S.LATITUDE AS Latitude, S.LONGITUDE AS Longitude,
           C.Name AS Country, T.Year, T.Month, AVG(T.Temp) AS Temp
    FROM temperatures T
    LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
    LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
    WHERE C.Name = '{country}'
          AND T.Year BETWEEN {year_begin} AND {year_end}
          AND T.Month = {month}
    GROUP BY S.NAME, T.Year, T.Month
    """
  
    # I used .read_sql_querey to read the dtatbase datat and store it as Pandas DataFrame
    df = pd.read_sql_query(query, conn)
    
    # filter stations with at least min_obs years of data value and group them by the station ID 
    df = df.groupby('Station_Name').filter(lambda x: x['Year'].count() >= min_obs)
    
   
     # Calculate the estimated yearly temperature increase for each station
    yearly_changes = df.groupby('Station_Name').apply(
        lambda group: calc_temp_coefficient(group)
    ).reset_index(name='Estimated Yearly Increase (°C)')
    
    
     # Create a Plotly Express scatter mapbox plot
    fig = px.scatter_mapbox(
        df,
        lat='Latitude',
        lon='Longitude',
        hover_name='Station_Name',
        color='Temp',  # Use the calculated column as color
        height=600,
        **kwargs
    )
    
    # Set layout options and styling for the plot
    fig.update_layout(margin={"r":0,"t":0,"l":0,"b":0})
    
    # Return the figure
    return fig

import inspect

def analyze_seasonal_temperature_change(db_file, season, country=None, year_range=None):
    # Connect to the database
    conn = sqlite3.connect(db_file)
    
    # Define the SQL query to retrieve temperature data for the specified season
    query = f"""
    SELECT T.Year,
           CASE
               WHEN T.Month BETWEEN 3 AND 5 THEN 'Spring'
               WHEN T.Month BETWEEN 6 AND 8 THEN 'Summer'
               WHEN T.Month BETWEEN 9 AND 11 THEN 'Fall'
               ELSE 'Winter'
           END AS Season,
           AVG(T.Temp) AS Avg_Temperature
    FROM temperatures T
    LEFT JOIN stations S ON T.ID = S.ID
    LEFT JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(S.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
    """
    
    # Add conditions for year range and country filter if provided
    if year_range:
        query += f" WHERE T.Year BETWEEN {year_range[0]} AND {year_range[1]}"
        if country:
            query += f" AND C.Name = '{country}'"
    elif country:
        query += f" WHERE C.Name = '{country}'"
    
    # Group the data by year and season
    query += " GROUP BY T.Year, Season"
    
    # Execute the query and read the results into a DataFrame
    df = pd.read_sql_query(query, conn)
    
    # Close the database connection
    conn.close()
   
    # Visualize the data
    fig = px.bar(df, x='Season', y='Avg_Temperature', color='Season', title=f'Average Temperature in {season}')
    fig.show()
    
    return fig

import pandas as pd


import sqlite3
conn = sqlite3.connect("temps.db")

df = pd.read_csv("temps.csv")
df_iter = pd.read_csv("temps.csv", chunksize = 100000)


def prepare_df(df):
    df = df.set_index(keys=["ID", "Year"])
    df = df.stack()
    df = df.reset_index()
    df = df.rename(columns = {"level_2"  : "Month" , 0 : "Temp"})
    df["Month"] = df["Month"].str[5:].astype(int)
    df["Temp"]  = df["Temp"] / 100
    return(df)

# cleans the data and make sure we are using the variables we need 


df = prepare_df(df)
df.head()

#creats a table with all temps 
for i, df in enumerate(df_iter):
    df = prepare_df(df)
    df.to_sql("temperatures", conn, if_exists = "replace" if i == 0 else "append", index = False)


#creats a table with all the stations 
url = "station-metadata.csv"
stations = pd.read_csv(url)
stations.to_sql("stations", conn, if_exists = "replace", index=False)

countries= pd.read_csv(countries_url)
countries.to_sql("countries", conn, if_exists = "replace", index=False)

for result in cursor.fetchall():
    print(result[0])

CREATE TABLE "temperatures" (
"ID" TEXT,
  "Year" INTEGER,
  "Month" INTEGER,
  "Temp" REAL
)
CREATE TABLE "stations" (
"ID" TEXT,
  "LATITUDE" REAL,
  "LONGITUDE" REAL,
  "STNELEV" REAL,
  "NAME" TEXT
)
CREATE TABLE "countries" (
"FIPS 10-4" TEXT,
  "ISO 3166" TEXT,
  "Name" TEXT
)
